Tutorial.description: This tutorial is about the crafting system

Start.Content: Welcome to the Crafing Tutorial. It will explain StarMade's crafting and factory system.

StateA.Content: Crafting in StarMade is based on a "consistence" system. Every craftable element has an amount of other elements it is made from. These other elements again have other elements they are made off and so forth. You can compare this system with a tree that has branches.

StateB.Content: Consistence trees do not loop, so an element (the tree's root) is never in any of the branches of its own crafting tree.

StateC.Content:
The other system is using recipes. Recipes just determine fixed product lines.
For example: 10 of any ore capsule makes a meta mesh.

StateD.Content: Enough theory for now. Here is how you start with absolutely nothing but your initial personal power beam.

StateE.Content: StarMade's raw resources exist in two groups: Crystal shards and ores. Each planet part has two random resources, while the resources on asteroids are set per type. You'll find different types of asteroids depending on the distance between the sector and the star.

StateF.Content: To start, collect some raw ore by salvaging some resources with a basic ship or as astronaut. After you've done that, open your inventory with $INVENTORY_PANEL and click the 'Craft Capsule' button. This will open your personal capsule factory. You can also craft a factory block that is faster and more efficient.

StateG.Content: Put one type of shards or ores in it and leave the second slot empty (the processed product will use this slot). After a short time, you should be getting a lot of capsules from that type. Place those in your inventory.

StateG1.Content: You can click on the 'Production' button to check which raw resource will produce which capsule.

StateH.Content: After you made some capsules, click on the 'Micro' button in your inventory and place them there. You need 10 capsules of any(!) type to produce either metal meshes (ore capsules), or circuits (shard capsules). Those two are the base ingredients for most of the blocks in StarMade.

StateI.Content: When you have either 20 metal meshes or circuits, press on the 'craft macro' button to craft your first macro factory. The macro factory makes every craftable block in the game. You can only place this block on a station or a planet.

StateI1.Content: After you placed a macro factory you will see that it needs power to function. You can provide that power by shooting it with your personal power supply beam, or if you have them, placing down power recharge blocks. If you don't have any power blocks then it should focus to craft some in your new factory.

StateJ.Content: Open the macro factory with $ACTIVATE and click on change production. You can use the filter and type for example 'power' to quickly find power modules in the drop down menu. After you chose the power recharge module, you can click on graph to see exactly what you need for making that block.

StateK.Content: IMPORTANT: The factory will only do the last step of the graph. Every step below that will require it's own factory. In this example the only thing that this factory will consume is Metal Mesh and 'Active Varat Processore', which you need to produce in a separate factory (or change the production on this one).

StateL.Content:
You can of course craft multiple factories to do all these steps at once.
Furthermore you are able to link factories: Press $SELECT_MODULE on the factory you want to be able to take needed materials out for other factories and press $CONNECT_MODULE on those to connect them with it.

StateM.Content: A factory will take ingredients needed from all the factories that are connected to it. This basically enables you to rebuild a whole crafting tree. Then you can put in raw resources in the bottom and get the high level product on the top.

End.Content: This concludes the Crafting Tutorial. Thanks for reading, and thanks for playing StarMade!
